headline: Easy Marinated Pork Tenderloin
description: This recipe includes a delicious marinade for pork tenderloin that's easy to throw together in mere minutes to guarantee juicy, tender roast pork every time.

video.description: Quick and easy baked pork tenderloin.
video.name: Easy Marinated Pork Tenderloin

name: Easy Marinated Pork Tenderloin
recipeIngredient: salt and ground black pepper to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Whisk together the olive oil, soy sauce, garlic, mustard, salt, and pepper in a bowl.
Place the pork loin in a large resealable plastic bag and pour in the marinade. Marinate in the refrigerator at least 1 hour before cooking.
Preheat an oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
Transfer the pork loin to a baking dish; pour marinade over the pork.
Cook in the preheated oven until the pork is no longer pink in the center, 45 to 60 minutes. An instant-read thermometer inserted into the center should read 145 degrees F (63 degrees C).

review.reviewBody: Very good...easy. Marinated for 8 hours, left out the salt and convection baked it for 40 min to 145. Served it with sautéed spinach, applesauce, quinoa rice. and salad. Perfect
Delicious and easy! I added more garlic and some red chile flakes to keep His Lordship happy. He wants to have this again!
You don't need the salt. Also I preferred a quick search before roasting and it's a crime to cook out all the pink. Pork isnt chicken. Take it out at 135 degrees and let it rest for 5-10 min.

So amazing. I knew it would be salty if I marinated it for too long so I did mine for 3 hours and it came out so perfect! I also put mine on my Traeger grill instead of the oven. 375 degrees for about 25 mins. I will make this over and over.
I used garlic powder because I had not garlic on hand. Came up really well.

it was delicious, made as listed, however after this i will make again just no salt, and use a lot less of the soy sauce, only because we have had heart issues.

Outstanding marinade. Best Pork Tenderloin I've ever made. I grilled it on all sides and finished in a 300 degree oven till it got to over 145 degrees. So tender and juicy with a flavor that will knock your socks off

This is an easy and great recipe. I put the pork tenderloin in to marinade the night before then had hubby put in the oven before I got home from work. Served with cauliflower rice. I had all the ingredients on hand. Tender, juicy, and full of flavor.
My daughter and I made this the same day And we both loved it This is a keeper

I upped the temperature to 400 degrees and cooked it for 45 minutes. It came out perfect with a little pink in the middle. The meat was tender & juicy. Definately a keeper.
I did add a little Adobe to the marinade for a bit of flavor, but even without it, great recipe
GREAT

Very good marinade! I made it the night before, scored my tenderloins and let sit in the baggy for about 20 hours. I made the marinade as written except halved the soy sauce and did not add salt. I threw it in the crockpot for 4 hours for convenience. Thank you for sharing!

This is an easy, delicious recipe. Whenever I make it for my sister and her family, everyone eats it up - including the pickiest eater. I’ve also grilled it using the 7-6-5 method and it always turns out delicious. When I grill it, I boil the excess marinade to use as a sauce.
Quick and easy to plan and get ready. Delicious flavour and tender and moist!

I made this the first time according to the recipe. It was good, but I wished the flavor of the marinade was more pronounced. So *this* time, I doubled the marinade and sliced the tenderloin into 1.5" - 2" pieces. I let it marinate for at least two hours, stirring the pork in the marinade at least once. *Fabulous!!*
Went exactly by recipe and it was delicious. This is a keeper!

I've made this recipe multiple times and absolutely love it. I sometimes marinade it over night but most of the time and just make it and cook it. It always turne out amazing. I dont always have Dijon mustard so I've substituted for regular mustard and honest mustard and again, delicious. Thanks !

I LOVED this recipe. This may be the best pork roast I've EVER made and I used this marinade recipe. It was SO juicy, not dry or boring at all as some pork tenderloin roasts can be. Save the drippings and make gravy for the tastiest leftover hot pork sandwiches. I did not have any honey dijon mustard so I used regular dijon with a couple of tablespoons of local honey that I buy at farmer's market. I think I'll continue to make it that way because it worked so well. My husband loves to make cold pork sandwiches with this roast as well. But wait!!! There's more: I love to make hot and sour soup and I use some of the leftover drippings IN the soup and a couple of handfuls of the pork, cut into strips, in the soup as well. You may wonder why there are so many leftovers; well, there are only two of us and I buy the two-pack pork tenderloin roasts...so there is a lot of pork to make lots of good stuff with after the initial meal. Be careful not to overcook; the timing suggested in the recipe was perfect...let the roast rest and it will continue to cook a bit but not be dry. I used a thermometer to be sure of how "done" it was, as suggested. Enjoy!! BTW, I buy local Monterey Peninsula/Salinas honey. Great honey is made here. There is a book, "The Honey Bus," in case you're interested in a really good read and true story. Nope, I didn't write it, I don't even know the writer, but for people who love honey and who love to cook with honey, I highly suggest it for a good read.

I've made this a few times. It is a very flexible recipe - to add to. Thyme, crushed red pepper, brown sugar that was this time. We grilled it because it was a perfect night for grilling but I think I like it better in the oven.
Very easy recipe and full of flavor! I marinade the pork roast overnight.
Made this many times and I always leave out the salt and 1/2 the soy sauce. My family loves this dish.
I’ve made this twice now, very juicy and tasty results!
Great as written,although I didn't add salt and cooked for temperature not time
We have made this a few times now and it is delicious! The only thing we did different is we substituted the soy sauce for coco aminos because my kids can't have gluten.
So simple and delish!
Thanks for this lovely and easy recipe. I marinated it in the morning & made it for dinner. It was the most moist tenderloin I've ever had and great flavor.
great stuff- the marinate makes the pork taste on point.
It was good and easy. Not as flavorful as I hoped, but very tender.
Made the recipe with no changes. It was delicious. Will definitely make this again.
I’ve made this twice with no changes to the recipe, and it’s been great both times. Winner!

Made it for dinner last night it came out great my

The Family devoured this! Side of mashed potatos, mushroom gravy and green beans. Numm numm numm.........

GREAT RECIPE. The best pork tenderloin I have ever made! Very easy and flavorful! I added 3 cloves of garlic and marinated it in a zip lock bag in the fridge for 2 hours. After 1/2 hour at room temp I then cooked as directed with sliced potatoes on the side.

This was a very fast and easy marinade, which is what I needed. I actually cut the marinating time to 30 minutes because it was late and I had a family to feed. It had a lot of flavor so I don't think the full hour marinating time is necessary. I will say that I used low sodium soy sauce and added no salt and it was still VERY salty. And I am a salt lover. Just leave out the salt and use low sodium soy sauce, for sure.

Love this! I like to have mashed potatoes as a side but wanted a gravy. To get a nice gravy I Double the oil, mustard and soy sauce to allow for more drippings when tenderloin is done cooking. Reserve those drippings. Mix 1 tablespoon of cornstarch with 1 cup heavy whipping cream. Combine cream mixture with the drippings over low heat to create a gravy.
I made the marinade as written, but put it on my smoker grill at 240 for an hour. Turned out great!
Delicious! Made it exactly as written and marinated overnight.
This has been a favorite in my household for a couple of years now! Make a double batch and it’s perfect (just better doubled for some reason; both meat and sauce).
So easy and tasty-very economical too!
This was so easy and turned out great. Followed the recipe exactly and grilled the pork. My entire family commented on how good it was—we ate it all!

This has become one of my go-to favorite recipes. I use Inglehoffer Original Stoneground Mustard instead of the dijon mustard. I also recommend a meat thermometer. Ovens are all different and there's nothing like meat that cooked to the perfect temp and still moist. This is amazing! Even kids like it! I serve it with couscous, potatoes or rice because you will want all the extra juice!
Yummy. Even my picky son loved it
Delicious! I wasn't sure about the marinade when it was in my measuring cup, so I added some ground ginger. We barbecued the meat and it was fantastic!

We absolutely love this pork tenderloin. Every time I make it we comment on how good it is.

What a quick and easy meal. I used low sodium soy sauce and added a bit of cumin and dry sage. I also didn't have the honey mustard combo so I added dijon mustard and honey to equal 3 tablespoons. Very good marinade.

Used about 3/4 of the soy sauce and oil. 
The pork tenderloin was very lean, so added 3 strips of bacon on top.
Flavor and tenderness were perfect. I only wish there was a bit of a crust on the outside—there was no “crust” at all like you’d get with grilling it, but still it was delicious.
Great flavor. Took a little longer - about 90 mins- because the cut I had was thicker than normal.

I followed the directions exactly and it came out very tender. I used a low sodium Japanese soya sauce because that was what I had. I didn’t find it too salty, but there was way too much mustard. The mustard (honey Dijon) felt like it was burning my insides hours later. I actually soaked the leftover pork in several changes of water to get rid of the mustard. The tenderloin was cut into 4 pieces before marinating for 20 minutes, then an oven for 40 minutes at 350*F. I forgot the salt and pepper so we added that at the table but this is a keeper for sure for us.
great

Just a hint of pink and so tender! Don't overcook!!! We used the marinade as a gravy for the potatoes and pork. Sprinkled some red pepper flakes on top before went in oven because didn’t think to mix in the marinade. I am from the south we like some extra spice. It couldn't have been easier to prepare and I'm happy I found the recipe just won't be making this sauce .

I used tamari instead of soy sauce because of friend with gluten intolerance. I also used stoneground grey poupon because that was what I had on hand.
